ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Chris
Christopher
Christopher Aung

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: It's a great course! Logistically, though, it is very difficult to complete the assigned readings. It might be helpful, if in advance of the 2 weeks of meeting for class, the professors assigned students to post responses to some of the readings on Blackboard. This would help even out the pace of the semester.
The class was amazing.I wish it was spread over more than two weeks, as the pace was very intense. However, very very useful and at the same time inspiring course.
The professors' first hand experience and knowledge of environmental law issues around the world, and there ability to help us get in touch with people related to our interests.
The potential breadth of material to be covered.
The best thing were the Professors. Very nice interaction between them, the different backgrounds were complementary and provided a richness that I saw in few classes at FES.
The opportunity to cover a greatdeal of comparative law in the space of two weeks is a unique opportunity. Profs Robinson and Lee are world class experts in the subject and taught well together.
The time commitment was low. Two weeks and a paper was not too difficult to manage.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The pace and the intra-lecture organization. While the 10 lectures were each very well conceptually parsed out, it felt like the instructors just sort of engaged in a bit of an unorganized diatribe for the 3 hour topic each day, particularly Prof. Heng. While her insights on international matters and stories were great, in terms of true academic discourse and organization, the rigor of the lectures was lacking. I felt like Prof. Robinson was often holding back at times. Also, given the expanse of material to cover in such a short time period (yet for so long each day), perhaps better organization within lectures would also be better aided by different tactile teaching methods to change things up a bit and keep students engaged. Lastly, far less room for discussion than I had imagined.
The class could have used some additional focus. While everything discussed in class was interesting, at times we moved to topics that I would consider beyond the scope of environmental law.
If the readings were disseminated in the beginning of the semester, then students would have time to read them closely. During the two weeks it is hard to fit in careful reading of all the material.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Excellent.
Instructors were very receptive to email requests for paper help once the two weeks had wrapped up, so, much on your shoulders to actually use them for advice.
They were both available even when outside of New Haven (skype, email and telephone). I have never received so much attention from professors before.
The instructors and TA were excellent. Professor Robinson gave extremely useful comments for helping me shape my paper, and the TA was always accessible for advice on it.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Comparative environmental law is useful for anyone going into policy or international affairs.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to pursue a specific interests in environmental law in other countries.
I wanted to take an environmental law class.
It seemed incredibly interesting.
It gave me a reason to delve into a topic I was curious about for the term paper.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, but it was more difficult to work into the semester than I had anticipated.

I feel like I now have a pile of great reading to do over the summer. Because unfortunately, during the course, there just clearly wasn't enough time. Given that, the course didn't live up to my expectations in part because I didn't put in the time, but in part because I realized it just isn't humanly possible to do a 3 hour seminar daily for 2 weeks straight and gain actual, full breadths of knowledge. The lecture material would have been enhanced by the readings the Profs. did succinctly provide, however, the pure logistical time constraints made it such that the course was unable to live up to my academic expectations - I would have loved to have put more in and gotten more out, however, one person juggling other classes and life can only do so much (despite telling yourself "it's only two weeks...").
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
More than I expected.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Realize you're only human. It's a great amount of subject matter that will be fun to engage in, however, you have to be much more committed to this course than a normal course - there aren't any "off weeks" to make up work in - it's very bang bang bang.
Don't wait until the last week to write the paper. Give yourself plenty of time to perform the research and meditate on the discussion.
